--- Mattias Fagerlund <mattias@...>
wrote:

> I kinda feel that the inputs/outputs aren't exactly
> fair to NEAT. Could 
> anyone suggest some inputs/outputs that would suit
> NEAT better, but 
> wouldn't violate the Artificial Ant premise?

I've been thinking about modeling the ant mentioned by
Matt Buckland in his book. (a real ant)  This ant
lives on a Euclidean plane, not a digital array.  It
leave the origin traveling in a straight line of
random orientation.  After a random time it changes to
a new straight line direction.  It does this until it
hits a piece of food.  Then, it does the equivalent of
a vector summation, because it heads in a straight
line directly back to the origin!

Now the angles and distances are not necessarily
random, they are chosen by the ant.  Also, the vector
summation could be accomplished by adding each new
vector to the running total of the previous ones.

An ANN could be evolved that walked in a good search
pattern that kept it fairly close to the nest, like
some kind of spiral.  You would reward it for finding
food an penalize it for time or distance searching.


=====
Mitchell Timin
